content.description: Sit start the low left side of the boulder and traverse the sloping rail to its apex and mantle.
content.location: Behind the three boulders, including Sarcophagus, that are directly opposite/facing Riverdance. Look for the boulder with an obvious sloping rail.

content.description:
This line was previously done as a solid V11. But after a climber matched a thin hold after a rainstorm, the hold gave way and broke. Multiple times. The breakage left behind a slopey three-four finger gaston which is very difficult to power off of. 

 For those looking to try something very hard, other than "Dancing Queen" and "The Whole Shebang", sit-start on a decent crimp edge in front of the large rock. Pull on and move right hand up to a big gaston before firing up to the slopey left-hand gaston (the broken hold). From this hold, execute a very powerful left-hand bump move to a bad hold, or find the friction and lock it off and move righty up to the bad hold, before bumping to a sloping pinch. Match this pinch then dyno out left to a good hold. Once here topout on big holds direct or out right.
content.protection: 4 pads. There is a rock slab behind and to the left.
content.location: About fifteen feet left of "Riverdance"  on the obvious chalked holds.

content.description: Stand start. Climb up the middle of the slabby boulder.
content.location: Directly opposite of the Riverdance boulder.

content.description: A superb compression problem on bulletproof holds. Squat start low on a left hand crimp and right hand lower on a sloper crimp. Pull on with a slick foot or campus the first move up right hand before utilizing a left heel to gain the higher lefthand holds. From here figure out how to reach the jugs and then topout on good holds.
content.location: The obvious prow right next to the river.

content.description: Stand start high on the obvious large diagnol undercling rail/pinch. Pull onto the wall using biceps and some hard foot pressure along with core. Execute a few really fun and burly moves up left to some slopers and then hit a jug out right before topping out in v1 terrain.
content.location: To the Left of the arete with "Riverdance" This problem starts on a chest-level or so undercling pinch.

content.description: A unique start from the left into "Riverdance". Sit start and make hard right hand move to a sidepull crimp. From here make some hard tension moves into "Riverdance".
Stand start. Climb slopers up the short boulder.
content.location: Located on the right side of the long, flat-topped boulder that is to the right if you are looking straight on at Riverdance.

content.description: The direct to "Capeoira". Sit start at the base of the arete. Pull on a move upwards via water polished seams and slopers to an exciting top above the river.
content.protection: 2 pads, and a spotter. Punting at the top will result in going for a swim.
content.location: Just right of "Riverdance" on the obvious chalked holds. This line travels up the face rather than traversing into the arete.

content.description: The longest problem on the boulder. Starts 4 or 5 moves below Lord of the Dance. Start matched on the lowest obvious hold just before the waters edge with a big first move and climb into Lord. Sometimes water level can be an issue.
content.location: About 20 minutes from the parking lot straight down the main trail. There will be a large boulder in which you can walk on top of on the left, that is the Riverdance Boulder. Just follow the short climber path down and right from the top of the boulder.

content.description: Start sitting just above the water on a good right hand and a slightly smaller left hand. Pull on and trend leftwards up the bulge into Riverdance and finish up that problem. Adds about four or five moves into the V9. Super good compression climbing in an all-time location. If you can climb the grade and like to squeeze, step up!
content.location: This line starts down and right of the arete a few feet from the water. If your foot pops on the intro, it is likely you going to get wet!

content.description: Sit start on the left side of the overhanging wall on some good edges. Make a big move up Lefty then span out right to a sidepull. Move in lefty to another crimp then thrutch out righty to a bad sloping sidepull and execute a big bump to a meat wraplike pinch. A hard match followed by a few more long moves gains the top of the boulder.A little history of this climb. My brother, Troy, was working "Lord of the Dance" and I had a vision for a climb to the left from a stand start. I scrubbed it up for about half an hour and cleaned it off before I tried it. I could never figure out a sequence that worked and it felt very difficult. I showed the line to Troy and he didn't think it was climbable and didn't try it at all.About a year or so later, Troy sent me a video of Zach Galla climbing "Brass Knuckles". I was in shock and psyched to see that somebody else believed in the climb that I saw, scrubbed and tried. The line I had scrubbed ended up being the end sequence of the V14.
content.protection: 3-6 pads. The landing is fairly flat.
content.location: This boulder problem is found on the same overhang as "Riverdance" but on the far left. It shares the starting holds with "Stankins", which has yet to be climbed post-break.

content.description: Right on the river, this location is 4 stars by itself. Beautiful and secluded with a mostly flat landing. There are many problems on this boulder and the smaller boulders surrounding it. The descent down to the base of the boulder is slightly sketchy.
